prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors considered by the Panel—Handling of related cases

para.paratext: Experience handling related cases may be important to the Panel in selecting the transferee judge. This experience can come from handling cases involving different parties and facts, but similar issues, or cases that are factually related.[1] For example, the Panel has ordered transfer so the cases could be handled by a judge who had handled previous MDL litigation involving a corporate predecessor of the central defendant in the current cases.[2] Experience handling similar cases against a common party may also be significant to the Panel.[3] Experience handing a similar type of case, not even necessarily in the MDL context, may be noteworthy to the Panel.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

Consideration of experience in handling cases arising from the same litigation is discussed in this chapter. Selection of a transferee district on the basis of the experience of the transferee judge in handling related litigation is also covered in § 6:15.
See In re Global Crossing Ltd. Securities Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
See In re Service Corp. Intern., 323 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2004).

See In re: Natrol, Inc. Glucosamine/Chondroitin Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 26 F. Supp. 3d 1392 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: National Collegiate Athletic Ass'n Athletic Grant-in-Aid Cap Antitrust Litigation, 24 F. Supp. 3d 1366 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014) (experience handling related “Name and Likeness” litigation); In re Neurontin Antitrust Litigation, 217 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (experience handling “sham” patent cases).
